question: Question_06_(b)
statement:
A circle of radius 5 centered on the origin has the equation

\begin{align*}x^2 + y^2 = 25\end{align*} Find the equation of the line tangent to the circle
at the point (3, -4).
sols:
Our differentiation rules at this point only address functions that are
in the form $y = f(x)$. Thus our first step is to transform the equation
of a circle into this form by solving for \emph{y}.

\begin{align*}
x^2 + y^2 &= 25 \\
y^2 &= 25 - x^2 \\
y &= \pm \sqrt{25 - x^2}\end{align*}

Because our point of concern is on the lower half of the circle, we will
use the negative square root.

We now proceed to find the slope of the tangent line at (3, -4). First
we take the derivative using the chain rule.

\begin{align*}
f(x) &= -\sqrt{25 - x^2} \\
f'(x)&= - \frac12 (25-x^2)^{-\frac12}(-2x) \\
 &= \frac{x}{\sqrt{25-x^2}} \end{align*}

To find the slope, we plug \emph{x = 3} into the derivative to get:

$\displaystyle f'(3) = \frac{3}{\sqrt{25 - 3^2}} = \frac{3}{4}$

We now have a slope, $3/4$, and a point, $(3, -4)$. Plugging these into
our equation of a line we get:

$y + 4 = \frac{3}{4}(x - 3)$
hints:
It may help first to find an expression for the bottom half of the
circle by solving the equation of the circle for \emph{y}.
